head.title: The Encounter at the Gas Pump: Other Views

hedline.hl1: The Encounter at the Gas Pump: Other Views

abstract.p: Pat Sposato letter on Peter Applebome's July 2 column on how to react to black man playing loud and offensive rap music at gas station pump suggests that rudeness and inconsideration know no boundaries (S)

block.p: Dozens of readers responded to Peter Applebome's July 2 column. Here is a sampling of their reactions.

We Americans can divide ourselves into many categories besides rap vs. heavy metal vs. ''classic rock'' vs. jazz vs. classical music; representational art vs. abstract art, swing dance vs. modern dance vs. ballet, apartments vs. houses, condos vs. co-ops, etc., etc. and so forth. Off hand, I can think of a million or two.
Dozens of readers responded to Peter Applebome's July 2 column. Here is a sampling of their reactions.

We Americans can divide ourselves into many categories besides rap vs. heavy metal vs. ''classic rock'' vs. jazz vs. classical music; representational art vs. abstract art, swing dance vs. modern dance vs. ballet, apartments vs. houses, condos vs. co-ops, etc., etc. and so forth. Off hand, I can think of a million or two.

However, that does not divide us as human beings. If you perceive (and who can say one's perception is ''wrong'') rudeness and inconsideration as a form of subculture, may I timidly suggest that rudeness and inconsideration know no boundaries, any more than kindness and love. We need to work on the causes of columns like yours, which ask silly questions which beg silly answers:
You needn't question your right to ask someone to turn his car radio down, no matter what kind of music he is playing!
